body: so what constraints on data/input checks do we want? I guess we need to check the data type of series (real valued or missing)?

On the low level interface, I think we agreed on at least the following checks:
* `isinstance(X, pd.DataFrame)`
* `isinstance(y, (pd.Series, np.ndarray))`

They should be checked in all our methods I think.

A few other checks I can think of are:
* cells of X should contain either primitives or series in form of either `pd.Series` or `np.ndarray`
* series in cells of X should be of length >= 2 
* missing values
* consistency of series within the same column (extending pandas column typing), including equal length, shared time index, consistent type of series within column

Not sure whether to check these in our methods, or delegate them to the data container and only query them if required.

so for full flexibility, we should allow meta data loading, and characteristics from the data. So checks could include
isMultivariate
hasMissing
isUnequalLength
which could be called on load if the meta data is not present (or indeed to check meta data?)

Yes, most of our methods assume univariate time series data (at least until we implement bespoke methods to handle these cases), that should also be consistently checked (related to multivariate composites, see #36), so `X.shape[1] == 1`.
We should also use sklearn's `check_is_fitted` in predict/transform.
Another question is whether we want the `check_input` kwarg for estimators/transformers allowing users to disable input checks. I thought that would be a good idea initially, but I'm less sure now.

I dont know re check_input, but my opinion is that it is up to an estimator to check its capabilities, allowing user to disable checks sounds like it breaks encapsulation and may result in undetermined behaviour.

body: * common check if data is series or primitives (column typing)

Currently, error messages are not very helpful when passing tabular pandas dataframe (see e.g. #150). We need to add checks for nested format, either as part of the input validation functions or the pandas container.

repository.name: sktime

issue.body:
#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Major refactoring and clean up of existing functionality: 
- [x] folder reorganisation #229 
- [x] sklearn-compatibility checks, run sklearn's [estimator checks](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/developers/develop.html?highlight=rolling%20your%20own%20estimator)
- [x] consistent input checks for TSC #98 
- [x] consistent unit checks for TSC #251 
- [x] consistent is-fitted checks for TSC
- [x] inherit from sktime's BaseEstimator
- [x] linting #256 
- [x] fix warnings

#### Comments 
I had to remove a few classes which I couldn't make compliant with the basic scikit-learn API without major work, including
* `transformers/spectral_based`, see #224 for refactoring and adding it back 
* removed our version of `GridSearchCV` as it was essentially the same as the one in scikit-learn
* `HomogeneousColumnEnsembleClassifier`, but we still have the more flexible `ColumnEnsembleClassifier`
* removed optional `check_input` kwarg (or parameter passed to fit)
* moved strategies and tasks from `highlevel/` to `benchmarking/`, removed `highlevel/`
* removed our `Pipeline`, but sklearn's pipeline should be fully compatible
